The passage describes the emergence of blue fluorescent algae on Australia's east coast, specifically in Jervis Bay, New South Wales. Photographer Andy Hutchinson captured the neon glow illuminating one of Australia's popular beaches. The phenomenon is caused by millions of plankton emitting light, specifically a single-celled phytoplankton called Noctiluca scintillans. This algae blooms in the spring and autumn, and in 90% of cases, it occurs naturally. An oceanography expert from the University of New South Wales, Iain Suthers, explained that the algae gives off a luminous glow as a defense mechanism, preying on another type of algae called diatoms. A similar display was observed in Sydney's Manly Beach in August 2014.

The passage discusses new genetic tests that can determine the aggressiveness of breast cancer tumors and potentially spare some patients from chemotherapy. After surgery, cancer cells are screened, and women can be told within days whether they have a high or low risk of the disease returning. For some women, the test can accurately tell if the risk is as low as 5%, which is as good as or better than the odds for those who have chemotherapy. The majority of women with breast cancer are currently given chemotherapy following tumor removal to prevent recurrence, but the side effects can be difficult to live with. Experts believe that the risk of cancer recurrence for certain women is lower than for others, and for some, chemotherapy may not be necessary. If the newest test, called Endopredict, shows a low score, patients can opt not to have chemotherapy. Most of these tests are currently only available privately, but breast specialists hope they may soon become available on the NHS. Surgeon Hemant Singhal and Professor Kefah Mokbel support the use of this test, stating that it can help patients make informed choices and potentially save costs by avoiding unnecessary chemotherapy.

The passage discusses the issue of women being airlifted from Royal Navy ships due to pregnancy. At least 25 women have been airlifted from these ships, with one ship, HMS Ocean, having five pregnant sailors removed in emergency "medevacs" over nine years. At least one woman was airlifted from HMS Illustrious, which was nicknamed "HMS Lusty" by the crew before it was decommissioned. Eighteen other ships had emergency evacuations due to pregnancy. The Ministry of Defence confirmed a strict "no touching" rule at sea, suggesting the women conceived before boarding the ships or during leave. The passage also mentions that women have been serving on Royal Navy ships since 1990, with around 9% of personnel being female in 2014. In 2015, three women became the first female submariners to serve in the Royal Navy. Nearly 100 female British soldiers were sent home from Afghanistan after finding out they were pregnant between 2006 and 2013. Sixteen women were removed from Afghanistan in 2013 due to pregnancy, and 18 were sent home in 2011. A further 102 women were evacuated from Iraq. Strict military rules ban mothers-to-be from serving in war zones, and troops are reminded to check they are not pregnant before flying to the front line. Most babies would have been conceived before the mother left the UK, but a small number of women may have become pregnant on tour.

tokyo ( cnn ) a bizarre and alarming discovery is raising concerns in japan about the potential for terrorism involving drones .
a drone carrying traces of a radioactive material was found on the rooftop of japan 's equivalent to the white house on wednesday , police and government officials said .
the discovery came on the same day a japanese court approved a government plan to restart two reactors at the sendai nuclear power plant in kagoshima prefecture , more than four years after the fukushima daiichi nuclear disaster .
prime minister shinzo abe 's push to restart the reactors is unpopular among many japanese , who view nuclear energy as too dangerous .
a staff member spotted the drone wednesday morning on the roof of abe 's residence , tokyo metropolitan police said .
dozens of police investigators were dispatched to the roof to investigate the origin of the drone , which had four propeller and was 50 centimeters ( 20 inches ) wide .
police say the drone was equipped with a small camera , smoke flares and a plastic bottle containing small traces of a radioactive material believed to be cesium , a common byproduct of nuclear reactors .
cesium was also discovered in areas around the failed fukushima daiichi nuclear plant after its 2011 meltdown .
investigators suspect the cesium was placed in the bottle .
the amount inside is not immediately harmful to humans .
chief cabinet secretary yoshihide suga said the discovery is raising concerns about terrorism .
" there might be terrorism attempts in the future at the olympics and g7 summit using drones , " suga said .
" so we need to examine and review continuously the way small unmanned vehicles like drones should be operated and how to cope with the threat of terrorism from drones .
the government will do all that we can to prevent terrorism . "
japanese law restricts drone flights around airports to prevent problems with aircraft , but there are no flight restrictions for most of tokyo , including the prime minister 's residence and local and federal government buildings .
abe was not in his office at the time .
he is in indonesia , attending the asian-african conference .
cnn 's elizabeth joseph, joshua berlinger and josh levs contributed to this report .

The passage discusses a major study conducted by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation at the University of Washington, published in the American Journal of Public Health. The study found that heavy drinking among Americans rose by 17.2 percent between 2005 and 2012, largely due to rising rates among women. Heavy drinking is defined as exceeding an average of one drink per day for women and two drinks per day for men. Binge drinking, defined as four or more drinks for women and five or more drinks for men on a single occasion at least once during the past month, also increased. The study is the first to track adult drinking patterns at the county level, revealing significant variations in binge drinking rates across different regions. Factors contributing to the increase in excessive drinking include changing social norms, increased acceptance of women drinking like men, young people's tendency to binge drink, affluence allowing for more spending on alcohol, cheaper alcohol prices due to lack of tax increases, increased alcohol advertising, and weakened alcohol control policies. The study highlights the growing concern over excessive drinking and its associated health risks and costs.

This trend is partly due to women opting for planned caesareans out of anxiety about natural birth. Experts from the WHO state that while caesareans can save lives, they are often performed without medical necessity, leading to complications and diverting resources from other patients. The passage describes the discovery of an Omura's whale, a species previously feared to be extinct, on a west Australian beach. The passage describes Firechat, an app developed by Open Garden that allows users to chat without needing web or mobile signals. Greenstone, a small egg-shaped device developed by Open Garden, acts as a beacon or booster to strengthen these wireless mesh networks, allowing messages to move around more easily. Firechat has been downloaded over five million times and is particularly useful in situations where there is no connectivity, such as on planes or in underground areas. Greenstone is designed to solve the limitation of how far a message can travel in this network, which is around 200ft (61 meters), and is currently under development to work with Firechat at a range of around 20ft (6 meters).

Theo Walcott, an Arsenal winger, has been frequently overlooked for matches this season and has been seen sitting on the bench alongside his teammates Calum Chambers, Jack Wilshere, Mikel Arteta, David Ospina, Mathieu Flamini, and Mesut Ozil. They recently participated in a photoshoot for Paris' oldest fashion house, Lanvin, alongside runway model Olga Sherer. Walcott, who has been on the substitutes' bench for 17 out of Arsenal's 33 Barclays Premier League games, is expected to make his first Arsenal start since March 14th when the team faces Hull at the KC Stadium on Monday.

The passage describes an upcoming auction of a collection of props and puppets created by legendary makeup effects artist Rick Baker, which will be held on May 29 at the Hilton Universal City in Los Angeles, California, and on Propstore.com. The collection, estimated to be worth $746,100, includes items from various films such as "Men in Black," "Batman Forever," "How the Grinch Stole Christmas," "Alien," "An American Werewolf in London," "Planet of the Apes," "Batman & Robin," "Hellboy," "Mighty Joe Young," "Michael Jackson's Moonwalker," and "Gremlins 2: The New Batch." Some of the notable items include a $40,000 Edgar Bug from "Men in Black," a $1,500 two-face mask from "Batman Forever," an $8,000 Grinch costume from "How the Grinch Stole Christmas," a $30,000 Mikey costume from "Men in Black," and a $10,000 worm guy from "Men in Black II." The auction is expected to attract collectors and fans of the make-up artist, with items spanning his 30-plus years in the business.

The family of a seven-year-old British boy, Carwyn Scott-Howell, who died in the French Alps, is devastated and describes the incident as leaving a "vast void in their hearts." Carwyn was skiing with his family when he became separated from his mother and headed into dense woodland, falling over a 164ft drop. His mother, Ceri, 44, desperately tried to find her missing son. Footprints in the snow eventually led police to his body. Carwyn was described as a daring, outgoing, and determined youngster who loved skiing and modeled himself after TV adventurer Bear Grylls. His family spent a happy ski holiday in Flaine, France, before the tragedy. Carwyn's friends and schoolmates have written in a condolence book, expressing their grief and missing him.

**Summary:**
Laura Scurr, a 15-year-old from Whitley Bay, developed anorexia after becoming obsessed with her weight and feeling pressured to be a "size zero." She hid food, ate very little, and eventually collapsed due to starvation. Laura's story highlights the pressures young girls face to conform to unrealistic beauty standards, leading to serious health consequences. After receiving support from eating disorder organizations, she began her recovery and participated in a competition aimed at promoting positive body image among young girls.

**Summary:**
Liverpool FC unveiled its new 2015/16 home kit, designed by US sports brand New Balance, at Anfield. The kit launch featured players Raheem Sterling, Daniel Sturridge, Philippe Coutinho, Jordan Henderson, and Simon Mignolet. The new design, which includes all-white branding and a unique collar style, was introduced to enthusiastic fans. Liverpool is committed to retaining its key players, including Sterling, for the upcoming season. The kit also includes a memorial flame and number 96 in tribute to the Hillsborough disaster victims.

**Summary:**
The University of Manchester has produced the largest high-definition map of dark matter, covering 0.4 percent of the night sky. This map, created using data from the Dark Energy Survey (DES) conducted with the 13-foot Victor M. Blanco telescope in Chile, shows clumps of dark matter in red and less dark matter in blue. The goal is to eventually map 12.5 percent of the sky over five years to create a 3D view of dark matter and dark energy. The map helps astronomers study galaxy formation and the nature of dark energy, which is believed to accelerate the universe's expansion. The DES, led by Fermilab, uses the Blanco telescope and its Dark Energy Camera to capture detailed images of galaxies, analyzing over 130 million separate telescope images to construct the map. This research supports current cosmological theories that galaxies form in regions with large concentrations of dark matter.

Marco Rubio believes that people are born with a sexual preference, but he thinks that the definition of marriage should be between one man and one woman. He also stated that states should have the authority to decide on the definition of marriage, and that courts should not make this decision. Rubio does not believe that same-sex marriage is a constitutional right. He has expressed that if someone he cares about is involved in a same-sex union, he would attend the wedding, even if he disagrees with the decision. Rubio, as a Catholic, believes that divorce is wrong but would not stop loving someone if they were divorced. He announced his candidacy for president last week, and donors have committed monetary support exceeding the $51 million he will likely need for the presidential primary season.

Pablo Mandado and Ilze Zebolde are a couple who quit their restaurant jobs in Manchester to embark on a year-long, budget-friendly journey around the world. They have been cycling for 356 days and covered almost 7,000 miles (11,131.92 km) through 16 countries. They live on less than three euros each day, relying on free accommodation, cycling for transportation, and minimal expenses for food. They often camp under the stars, use hosting websites like Couchsurfing and Warmshowers, and sometimes receive kindness from strangers for shelter and meals. Their journey has taken them through France, Spain, Portugal, Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Greece, Turkey, Georgia, and Armenia, with plans to continue into Asia and cycle the length of the American continent.

The passage describes a lawsuit filed by a couple from Texas against James Evans, the owner of Premiere Photos, over racist remarks allegedly made on photo booth snapshots from their 2012 wedding. The couple, who wished to remain anonymous, hired attorney Cathy Hale to sue the company for providing a photo booth that printed "poor n***** party" on the bottom of the pictures. The bride's sister informed the family about the racist incident months after the wedding. Despite the groom's horror upon hearing about the photos, Evans allegedly refused to apologize and told the couple to "sue him." The couple is suing Premiere Photos under the Texas Deceptive Trade Practices Act, alleging negligence and breach of contract. The company denies all allegations and claims there is no evidence linking them to the offensive caption. The couple's lawyer, Cathy Hale, stated that their primary concern is an apology from Evans, not financial gain. Mediation is scheduled for the following day, with a trial set for July if an agreement is not reached.

Mike Brown, the England full-back, is cautious about his return from a recent concussion. He pulled out of Harlequins' Aviva Premiership match against Saracens at Wembley last weekend due to ongoing symptoms. Northampton wing George North has been advised by medical experts not to play again this season after suffering four concussions in quick succession. Ireland's Johnny Sexton was also stood down for 12 weeks earlier in the term. Brown emphasizes the importance of being cautious and not rushing back too soon, as prolonged breaks can be detrimental. He learned about the symptoms of concussion through World Rugby online modules, which helped him realize he was not ready to face Ireland in the Six Nations match. Brown encourages teammates to prioritize their health and not play on if they show symptoms, as pushing through can be dangerous.

**Summary:**
Professor David Spiegelhalter suggests that increased smartphone use and technological connectivity may be contributing to a decline in the frequency of sexual activity among couples in Britain. Research indicates that the number of times a typical heterosexual couple has sex per month has decreased from five times in 1990 to three times in 2015. Factors contributing to this decline include the blurring of boundaries between public and private lives, increased email checking, and a general increase in busier lifestyles with less time dedicated to personal relationships. Catherine Mercer, a researcher, notes that competing demands on time and late-night work email checking can reduce the focus needed for intimate moments.

The passage describes the dramatic decline in popularity and value of Tibetan Mastiffs in China. Once highly sought after and commanding prices up to £1.2 million each, these dogs are now being sent to slaughterhouses and their meat used in cheap hotpots due to the Chinese government's anti-corruption crackdown and bans on owning large dogs in several cities. The breed's decline is also attributed to the deterioration of their quality due to cross-breeding for profits and the realization by many Chinese people that Tibetan Mastiffs are not well-suited for city living due to urbanization.

**Summary:**
A survey of women in Paris found that every woman reported experiencing some form of sexual harassment on public transport, with half being assaulted before age 18. Harassment ranged from insults to sex attacks, often going unreported due to women feeling conditioned to accept low-level abuse. This widespread issue led to calls for campaigns to address sexist or threatening behavior on public transit, with women altering their daily lives to avoid confrontation. The problem was described as excluding women from public spaces and was deemed a fundamental freedom issue.

**Summary:**
Direct Line, a company based in Leeds, has launched a competition called #EverydayFix, inviting groups to design prototypes to address common everyday emergencies. Participants were asked to identify their top ten everyday emergencies, such as forgetting to lock the door, losing keys, being stuck in traffic when late, and running out of phone battery. Three prototypes were shortlisted: the Forget Me Lock, which reassures users that their door is locked; Nipper, the world's smallest mobile phone charger that uses any household battery; and Snooze, an alarm clock that silences phone notifications to ensure a good night's sleep. The winning product will be funded through a Kickstarter campaign. Direct Line aims to support innovative solutions to everyday problems, with feedback from industry experts highlighting the potential of the prototypes to solve real-life emergencies.

**Summary:**
The police and crime commissioner for Northumbria, Vera Baird, is under investigation by the Ministry of Justice for allocating over £500,000 of public funds to a charity she runs alongside Northumbria Police Chief Constable Sue Sim. Critics accuse Baird and Sim of creating a "soap opera" within the force and of a conflict of interest, as the charity, Victims First Northumbria, was established to support crime victims but is partly run by Sim, who previously faced misconduct proceedings over alleged workplace bullying. The investigation will determine whether any conflict of interest rules were violated.

The passage describes a horrific assault on a 53-year-old man, Greg Valecce, by a gang known as the 'Tattoo Terrorists' in Philadelphia. The ringleader, Corey Campbell, 21, believed Valecce had hurt his cat and held him captive in the basement of Campbell's mother's house for three days, during which he was beaten, tied to a chair, and covered in offensive tattoos. Valecce suffered severe injuries, including busted ribs and fractured bones. The gang filmed the abuse, which was played in court. Campbell was sentenced to 20 years in prison, while his girlfriend Sandra Ng, 19, received 23 months in state prison, and another accomplice, Carl Halin, 18, also got 20 years. David Thomas, 28, is awaiting sentencing, and Jennifer Pratt, 40, is awaiting trial. Valecce has since had the tattoos removed but continues to suffer from nightmares and emotional distress.
